de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.controller.datageneration.distribution
Class ProbabilityDistribution

java.lang.Object
  de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.controller.datageneration.distribution.ProbabilityDistribution
All Implemented Interfaces:
ObservableDistribution, ObserverFillBehaviour, java.lang.Cloneable
Direct Known Subclasses:
NormalDistribution, UniformDistribution
public abstract class ProbabilityDistribution
extends java.lang.Object
implements ObservableDistribution, ObserverFillBehaviour, java.lang.Cloneable

Probability distributions are a fundamental concept in statistics. We need it to simulate random numbers using a specific probability distribution.

Event
An event is any occurrence that has a probability attached to it. In other words, an event is any outcome where you can say how likely it is to occur.

Probability is measured on a scale of 0 to 1. If an event is impossible, it has a probability of 0. If it's an absolute certainty, then the probability is 1.

Distributions
In general probability distributions are divided in two subsets:
  • discrete probability distribution
  • continuous probability distribution
Discrete Probability
A discrete probability function can take a discrete number of values. This means that it can only take exact values. Each of these discrete values has a certain probability of occurrence that is between [0, 1]. That is, a discrete function that allows negative values or values greater than one is not a probability distribution.

Continuous Probability
A continuous probability function can take countless values. It's frequently data that is measured in some way rather than counted, and a lot depends on the degree of precision you need to measure to. Continuous data is like a smooth, continuous path. With this probability function you need to focus on a particular level of accuracy and the probability of getting a range of values.

Since:
Apr/20/09
Version:
0.1
Author:
Michael Munz

Method Detail

generateExpectedValues

public abstract java.util.Map<java.lang.Double,java.lang.Double> generateExpectedValues()
this method generates the expected values for any probability distribution. Expected values form the shape of a probability distribution, like the bell curve of a normal distribution.

Visualizing
This method is intended to support in the decision of choosing the right probability distribution by visualizing it.

X, P(X=x)
X is a variate and follows any probability distribution with the probability P(X=x).

Returns:
Map(X, P(X=x))

generateValues

public java.util.Map<java.lang.Double,java.lang.Double> generateValues(int n)
generates values with the help of this probability distribution. This is the most convenient way to get values following the subject to probability distribution. The parameter passed in tells something about how many values are expected to be generated. Because there are no further setting the default random number generated is used. This is one way to make is easier to the user. Because the tester doesn't have to know anything about random number generators.

Convention on returned values
All numbers generated by this method are stored in a collection object. More precisely, in a map. This information will you to get the values correct out of it.

Suppose you've passed in n as 5. This means there will be five random numbers returned. So the overall size of the object returned is five, too.

The map object consists of two digits as double values.
The 1st is the key value and is used as an index while the 2nd value holds the actual value. In that context the value is any generated random number. To get the values you need the corresponding keys. Because the keys are the indices, as mentioned already, you get the values by using the indices.

Parameters:
n - how many values are supposed to get returned?
Returns:
a list with values stored in a map collection object.

generateValues

public java.util.Map<java.lang.Double,java.lang.Double> generateValues(int n,
                                                                       PRNG random)
generates values with the help of this probability distribution. This method is useful when testers want pass it's own random number generated which is used in the generation process. Instead of using the default RNG the passed down RNG is used.

Random number generators
There are a handful of different RND's shipped with. The full list of them and there advantages and backdraws are listed in PRNG. Use this informations to make your choice.

Notice, it is possible to use any RNG not used those listed above. Any RNG implementing java.util.random would be a possible candidate.

Parameters:
n - states, how many values to generate
random - tells which random number generated to use for generating numbers.
Returns:
list of generated numbers.

generatorInt

protected abstract org.uncommons.maths.number.NumberGenerator<java.lang.Integer> generatorInt(java.util.Random random)
creates a random number generator. Random number generators help us to generate a sequence of independent random numbers with a specified distribution. It's important to make distinction between random numbers and pseudo random numbers.

Random numbers
Truly random numbers must introduce some non-deterministic input. Some real world phenomenon that is unpredictable. Computer are deterministic and they're generally incapable of doing things at random.

Pseudo random numbers
Since computer cannot generate random numbers, the idea is, for a given probability distribution, to develop an algorithm such that the numbers appear to be random with the specified distribution. So pseudo random numbers are not really random at all. They are the result of deterministic mathematical formulae. Pseudo random number generators (PRNG) start with a single numeric seed value.

Parameters:
random - any PRNG which extends Random interface of the Java.util.Random can be plugged in.
Returns:
Interface for providing different types of sequences of numbers

generatorDouble

protected abstract org.uncommons.maths.number.NumberGenerator<java.lang.Double> generatorDouble(java.util.Random random)
creates a random number generator. Random number generators help us to generate a sequence of independent random numbers with a specified distribution. It's important to make distinction between random numbers and pseudo random numbers.

getDefaultRNG

public final java.util.Random getDefaultRNG()
gets the default random number generator.

Returns:
Mersenne Twister

getExpectation

public abstract int getExpectation()
Expectation gives a prediction of the results. The expectation of a variable X is like the mean, but for probability distributions. The expectation gives the typical or average value of a variable but it doesn't tell anything about how the values are spread out.

E(X) = ΣxP(X=x)
E(X) = μ

Returns:
E(X) = μ

getVariance

public abstract double getVariance()
Use variance to measure the spread of values. In other words, variance tells you about the spread of the result.

Var(X) = E(X-μ)²
E(X-μ)² = Σ(x-μ)²P(X=x)

Returns:
Var(X) = E(X-μ)²

getStandardDeviation

public abstract int getStandardDeviation()
As well as having a variance, probability distributions have a standard deviation. It's a way of measuring how far away from the center you can expect your values to be.

σ = √Var(X)

Returns:
σ = √Var(X)

getDescription

public abstract java.lang.String getDescription()
gets an description of this kind of probability distribution. That is, the name of the distribution, the expectation and the variance.

The general form of any description is like:

  • probability distribution, E(X), Var(X)

Returns:
probability distribution, E(X), Var(X)

isDiscrete

public abstract boolean isDiscrete()
Distributions
In general probability distributions are divided in two subsets:
  • discrete probability distribution
  • continuous probability distribution
Discrete Probability
A discrete probability function can take a discrete number of values. This means that it can only take exact values. With this probability function you need to focus on a particular level of accuracy and the probability of getting a range of values..

Returns:
true, if discrete

getN

public final int getN()
this is the N = Σn_i value from fill behaviour. It is passed down here with the observer pattern.

We need that value to get the distribution to work properly.

Returns:
N = Σn_i
